question: Question_B_06_(a)
statement:
Consider the triangle \emph{T} in three dimensions with vertices
\emph{(0, 1, 2)}, \emph{(1, 1, 5)} and \emph{(â1, 2, 2)}. Consider
also the plane \emph{P} that contains \emph{T}.

What is the area of \emph{T}?
sols:
The area of \emph{T} is half of the area of \textbf{a} parallelogram
with vertices \emph{(0, 1, 2), (1, 1, 5)} and \emph{(â1, 2, 2)}.
Meanwhile, the area of a parallelogram is the magnitude of the cross
product of vectors of two adjacent sides.

A convenient choice of vectors representing two adjacent sides are the
ones with common vertex \emph{(0, 1, 2)}. They are \emph{(1, 1, 5) - (0,
1, 2) = (1, 0, 3)} and \emph{(-1, 2, 2) - (0, 1, 2) = (-1, 1, 0)}

Hence,

\[T = \frac{1}{2} \left|(1,0,3) \times (-1,1,0)\right| = 1/2 \left|(-3,-3,1)\right| = \frac{\sqrt{19}}{2}\]
hints:
Don't fall back to the elementary method of calculating base and height.

There is a linear-algebraic formula for area of parallelogram which you
can make use of.
